news_header: Sam Altman rejected Elon Musk's $97.4bn bid to take over OpenAI, amidst ongoing tensions between the two over the company's future.
news_original_title: ChatGPT boss says no thanks to Elon Musk-led $97bn bid
news_text: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, has turned down a $97.4bn takeover bid from a consortium led by Elon Musk. Musk's attorney confirmed the bid for all assets of OpenAI, which has been at the center of a long-standing conflict between Musk and Altman regarding the startup's direction. Altman humorously responded on Musk's platform X, suggesting a counter-offer to buy Twitter. While Altman's rejection doesn't end the takeover possibility, OpenAI's board will ultimately decide. Musk and Altman co-founded OpenAI in 2015, but their relationship has deteriorated since Musk's departure in 2018. Altman is restructuring OpenAI into a for-profit entity, which Musk argues contradicts its original mission. The bid is significantly lower than OpenAI's recent valuations, and Musk's motives are questioned, especially as he has a competing for-profit AI venture. Additionally, Musk is involved in a new $500bn AI infrastructure project with Oracle and other investors, announced by Trump as a major initiative for the US.
